Overall presentation reflects sustained, hard-to-control worry across multiple areas for months with prominent somatic/cognitive anxiety symptoms and impairment, alongside a concurrent 7–8 week episode of depressed mood and loss of interest with neurovegetative changes, guilt/worthlessness, impaired concentration, and passive suicidal ideation causing significant distress and functional decline.

demographics: 29-year-old woman, works as a marketing project coordinator at a mid-sized tech company; lives with a roommate; completed college; no current substance use; drinks 1–2 coffees daily; no significant medical history; family history notable for an older brother with longstanding academic and organizational difficulties and a mother described as a “worrier.”
clinical_text:
Chief concerns: “My mind doesn’t shut off, and I can’t keep up at work even when I’m trying.”

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation due to chronic difficulties with attention, organization, and follow-through, alongside persistent and hard-to-control worry. She reports that for at least the past year she has been “on edge almost every day,” worrying about multiple areas: job performance and being fired, finances, her parents’ health, and making mistakes that “will ruin everything.” She describes the worry as excessive compared with peers: “Everyone’s stressed, but I spiral for hours.” She finds it difficult to control and notes that even when one concern is resolved, “my brain immediately finds a new thing to worry about.” She endorses associated symptoms occurring on most days: restlessness (“I feel keyed up like I can’t relax”), easy fatigue (“I’m exhausted by midafternoon even if I didn’t do much”), trouble concentrating (“I read the same email five times and still miss details”), irritability (“small stuff sets me off and then I feel guilty”), muscle tension (tight shoulders/jaw with frequent headaches), and sleep disturbance (takes 60–90 minutes to fall asleep due to rumination; wakes unrefreshed). She reports functional impact: decreased productivity, avoidance of tasks perceived as high-stakes, and strained relationships due to irritability.

In parallel, she describes longstanding patterns of inattentive and impulsive behavior that predate her anxiety. She recalls difficulties beginning in elementary school: “Teachers said I daydreamed, forgot homework, and my desk was a disaster.” She reports that by age 10 she frequently lost school materials, left assignments unfinished, and needed repeated reminders. In middle and high school she did “well on tests but turned things in late,” often completing work the night before and misjudging time. She denies that these early difficulties were due to mood episodes, substance use, or unstable housing.

Current symptoms include frequent careless mistakes at work (e.g., sending drafts with missing attachments, overlooking line items), difficulty sustaining attention in meetings (“I try, but five minutes in I’m mentally somewhere else”), and trouble completing tasks despite intent (“I start a project, then I’m pulled to something else and the first thing just sits”). She describes poor organization and weak time management: multiple unfinished to-do lists, missed deadlines, and chronic lateness. She avoids or procrastinates on tasks requiring sustained mental effort, especially detailed reporting: “I’ll do anything else—clean my apartment, reorganize files—before I write the report.” She frequently misplaces items (badge, keys, phone) and is easily distracted by external stimuli and internal thoughts (“If someone walks by or Slack pings, I’m gone”). She also endorses forgetfulness in daily activities (forgetting appointments unless multiple alerts are set; leaving groceries in the car).

She notes symptoms consistent with hyperactive/impulsive tendencies in adulthood: feeling internally restless (“like a motor running”), difficulty sitting through long meetings, fidgeting, and talking excessively when anxious (“I interrupt without meaning to”). She reports blurting out answers in conversations and finishing others’ sentences, and she has trouble waiting her turn in group discussions. She describes making impulsive purchases online “to relieve the stress,” later regretting them due to financial impact.

Course and impairment across settings: The attentional and organizational difficulties occur at work and at home (missed bill payments, clutter, forgetting chores/commitments). She reports that these patterns have contributed to repeated performance feedback at work, including being placed on a performance improvement plan 3 months ago. At home, she has conflict with her roommate about shared responsibilities (“I genuinely forget, then I feel awful”). The chronic worry amplifies her impairment: she double-checks emails repeatedly, spends excessive time re-reading documents, and seeks reassurance from coworkers, which further delays task completion. She describes a self-reinforcing cycle: missed details or delays lead to intense worry about consequences, which then worsens concentration and increases procrastination.

Risk and safety: She denies current or past suicidal ideation, self-harm, or suicide attempts. No homicidal ideation. No history of psychosis or manic/hypomanic episodes. She denies panic attacks that come “out of the blue,” though she does describe sustained tension and occasional surges of anxiety related to work deadlines.

Substance/medical: She denies illicit substance use. Alcohol is limited to 0–2 drinks on weekends; she denies binge use. No misuse of stimulants or sedatives. She reports no thyroid disease, seizure disorder, or sleep apnea symptoms. Caffeine intake is stable and modest; she avoids energy drinks.

Mental status (summary): Well-groomed; cooperative; psychomotor mildly fidgety. Speech normal rate/volume but occasionally tangential when describing worries. Mood “stressed”; affect anxious but reactive. Thought process generally linear with occasional circumstantiality. Thought content notable for excessive worries and self-criticism; no delusions. Cognition intact; attention variable during interview (asked for a question to be repeated twice). Insight fair; judgment generally intact.

Patient quotes illustrating interaction: “I’m constantly worried I missed something, and then I’m checking so much that I can’t finish.” “If I try to focus, my mind wanders to all the ways I could mess up.” “I’ve been like this since I was a kid—always losing things—but the worry has gotten bigger as responsibilities grew.”

demographics: 29-year-old woman, lives with her partner, employed full-time as a project coordinator at a mid-sized software company. Completed a bachelor's degree. No current substance use; drinks 1–2 coffees daily, alcohol 1–2 drinks on weekends. No significant medical history reported; not pregnant.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: “My mind never shuts off, and I can’t stay on top of anything. I’m either scattered or stressed.”

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation of longstanding attention and organization problems with a more recent increase in persistent worry and physical tension. Over the past 8–10 months she has experienced excessive worry occurring most days about multiple areas: work performance (“I’m sure I missed something and it’ll blow up”), finances (“What if I get fired because I can’t keep up?”), her parents’ health (“If I don’t answer a text I assume something bad happened”), and her relationship (“I replay conversations and worry I said the wrong thing”). She describes the worry as difficult to control: “Even when I tell myself it’s unlikely, my brain keeps spinning.” She reports associated symptoms on most days including feeling keyed up and restless (“I’m on edge”), easy fatigue by afternoon, irritability (“small things set me off”), muscle tension in her neck/jaw with frequent clenching, and sleep disturbance characterized by prolonged sleep onset due to rumination and occasional early awakening.

Functionally, she spends significant time seeking reassurance and double-checking, which paradoxically worsens delays. She reports frequently rereading emails, rewriting to avoid mistakes, and checking her calendar repeatedly, yet still misses tasks: “I check ten times and still forget the one thing that mattered.” She denies discrete episodes of sudden terror with palpitations or fear of dying; her anxiety is described as persistent and spread across topics rather than brief surges. She denies intrusive unwanted images or repetitive rituals performed to reduce distress beyond the practical checking noted above. She denies current or past hallucinations or delusional beliefs.

Longstanding attention/organization symptoms: She reports a persistent pattern since childhood of difficulty sustaining attention, disorganization, and forgetfulness. At work she struggles to remain focused during meetings unless she is taking extensive notes; she “zones out” and realizes she missed key points. She frequently makes careless errors (e.g., attaching the wrong file, overlooking details in project timelines), has difficulty following through on multi-step tasks, and often starts tasks but shifts to others before finishing. She describes chronic procrastination and avoidance of tasks requiring sustained mental effort (e.g., preparing project reports), often waiting until the last minute with resulting stress and rushed work. She has difficulty organizing tasks and time, relies on multiple digital reminders that become cluttered, and still misses deadlines. She frequently misplaces items such as her badge, phone, and earbuds, and describes being easily distracted by unrelated thoughts or external stimuli (“If someone walks by or my phone buzzes, I’m gone”). She reports forgetting to return messages and forgetting appointments unless repeatedly reminded.

Hyperactive/impulsive symptoms are also present though less prominent than inattention: she frequently fidgets, taps her foot, and finds it hard to sit through long meetings. She often feels internally restless (“like a motor running”) and tends to talk quickly when anxious. She acknowledges interrupting others or finishing their sentences, especially when excited or worried about forgetting her point. She sometimes blurts out responses in meetings before others finish, later feeling embarrassed.

Developmental/childhood history: She reports that these attention and restlessness symptoms were present before age 12. She recalls teachers commenting that she was “bright but not working to potential,” frequently forgot homework, had a messy desk/locker, and was often distracted and chatty. Her parent corroborates that she needed repeated prompts for chores and often lost school materials. She reports similar difficulties across settings (school, home, and now work).

Course and impairment: She reports impairment in occupational functioning (missed deadlines, performance feedback about disorganization and not following through), interpersonal stress (partner frustrated by forgetfulness and unfinished household tasks), and increased distress due to worry about consequences. She describes a self-reinforcing cycle: missed details and procrastination increase worry and muscle tension; the worry then further disrupts concentration and sleep, worsening daytime attention and productivity.

Mood and safety: She reports feeling “stressed and overwhelmed,” but denies persistent depressed mood most of the day nearly every day for weeks, denies anhedonia, and denies current suicidal ideation or self-harm. She denies lifetime episodes of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, or risky behavior. Energy is variable and often reduced due to poor sleep and tension rather than episodic mood changes.

Substances/medical: She denies stimulant, cannabis, or other illicit drug use. She reports that symptoms occur regardless of caffeine intake, though excessive coffee increases jitteriness. No history suggestive of hyperthyroidism or other medical explanation is reported. No current medications.

Mental status exam (abbreviated): Well-groomed, cooperative. Motor: mild psychomotor restlessness with frequent fidgeting. Speech: normal volume, mildly rapid at times. Mood “anxious”; affect congruent, full range. Thought process linear but occasionally tangential when describing multiple tasks. Thought content notable for pervasive worries about multiple life domains; no psychosis. Cognition: alert and oriented; attention intermittently impaired during interview (asked for repetition of a question once; self-corrected). Insight and judgment fair.

Summary impression: The presentation is characterized by longstanding, cross-situational inattention with some hyperactive/impulsive features beginning in childhood and causing functional impairment, alongside persistent, difficult-to-control, excessive worry across multiple domains for more than 6 months with associated restlessness, fatigue, irritability, muscle tension, and sleep disturbance, contributing to significant distress and compounding attentional difficulties.

demographics: 32-year-old woman, married, works as a bank operations specialist; lives with spouse and one school-aged child. No prior psychiatric hospitalizations. Remote history of mild anxiety in college; no history of manic or hypomanic episodes. Drinks alcohol 1–2 drinks/month; denies illicit substance use.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: "I can’t stop reliving it, and I feel like I’m failing at everything."

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation of persistent distress and declining functioning that began after a high-speed motor vehicle collision 8 months ago. She was driving home from work when another car ran a red light and struck the driver’s side. She reports being trapped briefly, believing she would die, and witnessing the other driver bleeding and unresponsive until emergency responders arrived. She sustained a concussion and rib fractures; her physical injuries have healed, but she describes ongoing psychological symptoms.

Intrusive symptoms: She reports recurrent, involuntary, distressing memories of the collision occurring "out of nowhere," especially when hearing screeching brakes or sirens. She endorses recurrent nightmares 3–4 nights per week in which she "sees the headlights coming" and wakes in a panic, sweating and tachycardic. She describes occasional episodes while driving as a passenger where she feels "like I’m back in the car" for seconds to a minute, during which she grips the seat, becomes disoriented, and then feels ashamed afterward. She has marked physiologic reactivity (heart racing, nausea, trembling) when passing intersections similar to the crash site.

Avoidance: She actively avoids driving and has not driven since the accident, despite previously commuting daily. She refuses to ride in the front passenger seat and avoids the route where the crash occurred. She avoids conversations about the collision and becomes tearful or shuts down when family members ask about the legal/insurance process. She has stopped watching news or shows that include car crashes.

Changes in cognition and mood related to the event: She reports persistent negative beliefs about safety and herself: "The world isn’t safe," and "I should have seen it coming." She endorses ongoing guilt and self-blame about surviving while the other driver died, stating, "I don’t deserve to be okay." She describes emotional numbing and diminished ability to experience positive feelings: "Even when my kid is laughing, it feels far away." She feels detached from her spouse and friends, rarely socializes, and reports decreased interest in previously enjoyed activities (baking, weekend outings). She notes patchy memory for parts of the immediate aftermath of the collision (e.g., "I can’t remember the moments right after impact"), though she remains oriented with intact memory for other life events.

Arousal/reactivity symptoms: She reports chronic hypervigilance in public and in cars, constantly scanning for danger. She endorses exaggerated startle response to loud sounds, irritability, and snapping at family members "over nothing." Sleep is markedly disrupted by difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings; she averages 4–5 hours/night. She reports poor concentration at work, making errors in routine tasks and needing to recheck work repeatedly. She also describes restlessness and tension, with intermittent headaches and muscle tightness.

Depressive syndrome: Over the past 3–4 months, she has developed persistent low mood "most of the day, nearly every day" with anhedonia. She reports a significant drop in energy and motivation, stating, "It takes everything to get out of bed." Appetite has decreased with an unintentional 10-lb weight loss over ~2 months. She endorses feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt extending beyond the collision ("I’m a burden; my family would be better off without me"). She describes psychomotor slowing noted by her spouse ("She moves like she’s stuck in mud") and reports difficulty thinking and making decisions at work. She endorses passive thoughts of death several times per week ("If I didn’t wake up, it might be easier") and one episode of considering taking an excessive amount of her prescribed pain medication approximately 6 weeks ago; she denies current intent or plan, denies preparatory behaviors, and agrees to safety planning and restricting access to medications.

Course, impairment, and context: Symptoms have persisted for more than 6 months after the collision and have intensified over the last several months, leading to significant impairment. She is on a performance improvement plan at work due to mistakes and missed deadlines. She has avoided driving, increasing dependence on her spouse for transportation and childcare logistics, contributing to marital strain. She has withdrawn from friends and family and reports reduced engagement in parenting activities.

Medical/substance/medication factors: She denies current substance misuse. She takes only occasional ibuprofen; no steroids or stimulants. She denies thyroid disease or other medical explanation for symptoms. No evidence of delirium or psychosis. She denies past periods of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, pressured speech, or risky behavior.

Mental status (abbreviated): Appears stated age; tearful at times; psychomotor slowing; mood "empty" with constricted affect. Thought process linear; thought content notable for guilt and passive death wishes without current plan/intent. No hallucinations or delusions. Cognition grossly intact though concentration reduced. Insight and judgment fair.

Risk: Passive suicidal ideation with past consideration of overdose; no current plan or intent; protective factors include child, spouse, and willingness to engage in treatment. Safety plan initiated and follow-up arranged.

demographics: 32-year-old cisgender woman, married, works as an accounts payable specialist at a mid-sized manufacturing company; lives with spouse and a 4-year-old child; no current substance use; drinks 1–2 cups of coffee daily.
clinical_text:
Chief concerns: “I can’t shut my brain off” and “I don’t feel like myself.”

History of present illness: The patient reports a long-standing pattern of excessive worry that has been present most days for approximately 8–9 months. Worries are described as pervasive and difficult to control, spanning multiple domains including job performance (fear of making mistakes and being fired), finances (catastrophic thoughts about unexpected bills), her child’s health/safety (frequent mental images of accidents), and relationship stability (“I keep thinking I’m failing as a partner”). She describes spending hours mentally reviewing conversations and checking for errors, and says, “Even when nothing is happening, my body feels on alert.” She tries to reassure herself, makes lists, and asks her spouse for reassurance, but the worry returns quickly. She reports associated symptoms occurring on most days: feeling keyed up and restless (“I’m constantly bracing for bad news”), easy fatigability by mid-afternoon, difficulty concentrating (“I read the same email five times and still don’t absorb it”), irritability with family (“I snap and then hate myself for it”), muscle tension in her neck/shoulders with frequent headaches, and sleep disturbance characterized by difficulty falling asleep due to rumination and frequent early-morning awakenings.

Over the past 5 weeks, she has developed a distinct downturn in mood and functioning, which she describes as “a heavy, numb sadness” present nearly every day most of the day. She also reports markedly reduced interest and pleasure: she has stopped exercising, avoids social contact, and no longer enjoys activities she previously valued (baking and weekend outings). She reports low energy, psychomotor slowing (“I move like I’m underwater”), and diminished motivation to complete routine tasks such as laundry and meal preparation. Concentration has worsened beyond her baseline worry-related distractibility; she has made multiple minor bookkeeping errors at work and is behind on deadlines, leading to a written warning. She endorses feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt (“My family would be better off with someone who isn’t so broken”), and recurrent negative self-appraisals. She notes appetite has decreased with unintentional weight loss of about 6 pounds over the last month. Sleep is nonrestorative with early awakening and difficulty returning to sleep. She endorses passive thoughts of death on several occasions in the last two weeks (“Sometimes I think it would be easier not to wake up”), but denies intent, plan, preparatory behavior, or access to firearms. She identifies her child as a strong protective factor and agrees to seek help if thoughts intensify.

Functional impact: She reports significant impairment in occupational functioning (reduced productivity, errors, avoidance of tasks), social withdrawal, and strain in her marriage due to irritability and reassurance-seeking. She avoids driving on highways due to fear-based rumination about accidents and has missed several family events because she feels “too exhausted” and worries she will “ruin the mood.”

Psychiatric/medical history: No prior psychiatric hospitalizations. She attended brief counseling in college for stress but no sustained treatment. No history of episodes of abnormally elevated or expansive mood, decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity, or risky behavior. Denies hallucinations, delusions, or paranoia. Denies current or past panic attacks that are unexpected and recurrent. Medical history notable only for episodic tension headaches; recent primary care evaluation reportedly normal, including thyroid testing. No current medications other than occasional ibuprofen. 

Substance use: Denies alcohol misuse, cannabis, stimulants, or other illicit substances. No recent medication changes.

Family and psychosocial context: Family history includes a parent described as “a worrier” and a sibling with prior treatment for mood symptoms. She reports increased work demands over the last year and ongoing childcare stress, but states the mood decline feels disproportionate to any single event and has persisted despite attempts at rest and support.

Mental status (summary): Appears tired with constricted affect; mood described as “sad and on edge.” Thought process linear but ruminative. No psychosis. Cognition grossly intact though attention is impaired by worry. Insight and judgment fair. Safety: passive death wishes without plan/intent; agrees to a safety plan and follow-up.
